Precise regulation of MHC class II expression plays a crucial role in the control of the immune response .

The transactivator <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> behaves as a master controller of constitutive and inducible MHC class II gene activation , but its exact mechanism of action is not known .
Activation of MHC class II promoters requires binding of at least three distinct multi - protein complexes ( RFX , X2BP and NF-Y ) .
It is known that the stability of this binding results from cooperative interactions between these proteins .
We show here that expression of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in MHC class II - cells triggers occupation of the promoters by these complexes .

This observation raised the possibility that the effect of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on promoter occupation is mediated by an effect on the cooperative stabilization of the DNA - bound multi - protein complexes .

We show , however , that the presence of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> does not affect the stability of the higher - order protein complex formed on DNA by RFX , X2BP and NF-Y .

This suggests other mechanisms for <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced promoter occupancy , such as an effect on chromatin structure leading to increased accessibility of MHC class II promoters .
This ability of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to facilitate promoter occupation is undissociable from its transactivation potential .

Finally , we conclude that this effect of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is cell-type specific , since expression of <extra_id_0> CIITA <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not required for normal occupation of MHC class II promoters in B lymphocytes .
